docs.abstract: Letter by Dr Lawrence I Bonchek on March 12 articles on growing popularity of cheese and Emme Aronson, world's leading model for clothes size 12 and larger (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To The Living Section: It was disappointing that The Living Section of March 12 contained two articles about eating that ignored important health issues. The first, ''At Dinner, More Americans Are Saying 'Cheese' and Smiling,'' described the increasing popularity of serving cheese in restaurants, but it failed to point out that the main ingredients in cheese, salt and fat, should be avoided whenever possible. Is that something to smile about? The second article, ''Size 14, 190 Pounds: A Model Figure,'' was a paean to gluttony, in this case that of Emme, a highly successful ''plus size'' model, who manages to profit from her self-indulgence because she has high cheekbones and a pretty face that is less padded than her frame. Emme proudly asserts that ''a cookie is just a cookie,'' just as we used to say -- in a more innocent past -- that ''a smoke is just a smoke.''

docs.abstract: Study finds that black women burn nearly 100 fewer calories a day than white women do when their bodies are at rest; another study finds that men overeat when they are happy or excited while women overeat when they are depressed; depressed men appear to use food as a way to assert themselves, and women use food in futile effort to mask negative feelings (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Race and Weight THE fact that nearly half of American black women are overweight, as opposed to a third of white women, has often been attributed to differences in eating and exercise habits and attitudes toward body weight. But a new study published in the journal Obesity Research suggests that the higher rates of obesity among black women may be partly determined by biology. The study found that on average, black women burn nearly 100 fewer calories a day than white women do when their bodies are at rest. The difference remained even after adjusting for body weight and muscle mass.
